startupObject.name: Customize Schedule
startupObject.instructions:
Schedule: columns customized: 
Example -see ASCVD score and HCC numbers for each patient

Schedule: columns customized: 
Example -see ASCVD score and HCC numbers for each patient

Tip 7  Ambulatory Quick Wins
Schedule ‚Äê Choose Which Information Appears

You can see desired patient information in columns on your schedule as well as add and change the order of the
columns on the schedule.

1. Choose which personalized schedule view to personalize. On the top left of the schedule, beneath the
schedule toolbar, click the current view to see the list of views:
(This is usually your name in all caps with a ‚ñº).
2. After clicking on the desired view to edit, at the top of the view list window, click ‚öôS.
3. To change the columns, use the General tab of the window that opens:
 ‚óè Reorder columns: In the Selected Columns list, click ‚ñ≤ or ‚ñº at the bottom.
 ‚óè Add a column: In the Available Columns list > click on a desired column > click Add Column.
Some frequently‚Äêused columns are:
   ‚óã Referring: Shows the referring provider for the visit
   ‚óã H&P Note, H&P Status, or Case Request: For surgical workflows
   ‚óã Pre‚ÄêCharting: Indicates whether pre‚Äêcharting was done
   ‚óã Last Enc this Prov: Shows the last encounter you had with the patient
   ‚óã Last Enc this Dept: Shows the last time the patient was seen in this department
   ‚óã HM Due/Overdue: Shows Health Maintenance that is due for the patient
 ‚óè Remove a column: In the Selected Columns list, select the column and click Remove. For
example, you might want to remove the Provider column if your schedule view shows only your visits.
4. Click Accept to save your changes.

startupObject.name: Wrap Up Activity
startupObject.instructions:
Need speed button for plan of care fow medicare wellness visit.    Layout of Wrap Up pane
Add new speed buttons for level of visit.

Tip 17 - Visit Wrap Up - Personalize Level of Service
Edit the Level of Service activity to speed up end-of-visit documentation. You can add up to 25 LOS buttons and 4
modifier buttons. You can personalize button names and choose how the buttons are ordered and grouped. For
example, you could list the preventative LOS codes, or, if you work with residents, have the GC modifier one-click
away as a button.

1. On the bottom of the patient workspace, in the visit taskbar click Level of Service.
2. Click üîß.
3. Add a new button:
 ‚óè Click Add in an empty rectangle.
 ‚óè In the window that opens, add a Caption and Level of Service.
 ‚óè Click Accept on the window.
4. Add a modifier button:
 ‚óè Click Add in an empty rectangle in the Modifiers list.
 ‚óè In the window that opens, add a Caption and Modifier.
 ‚óè Click Accept.
5. Rearrange buttons: Drag and drop buttons to where you want them to appear.
6. Edit a button:
 ‚óè Hover over an existing button and click the edit pencil
that appears.
 ‚óè In the window that opens, edit as needed and click Accept on the window.
7. When done editing, click Accept.

startupObject.name: Note Speed Buttons
startupObject.instructions:
Create note speed buttons to only the note templates that are used. 
Examples: 
-progress note,
-telephone visit, 
-video visit

Tip 13 - Note Writing - Create Note Speed Buttons: Page-15

In outpatient documentation, note speed buttons are useful for your most frequently-used note templates. Speed
buttons can pull in SmartTexts and SmartPhrases.
Each button may be used create a new note if one does not exist, or they can be used to supplement the text
within a note.

1. In a patient's chart, go to Notes.
2. Click the üîß - Under the Progress Notes Speed Buttons section you will see a SmartPhrase and a SmartText field
to add new buttons.
3. To add another speed button, enter the name of the SmartPhrase or SmartText in the appropriate field and click Add.
4. In the Caption field, enter a free-text button name.
5. Click Accept.

To remove a speed button:
6. Hover over the speed button you want to remove and click the X.

startupObject.name: Create Letter Templates
startupObject.instructions:
Create letter templates for common correspondence
such as:
-school excuses
-work excuses

Tip 15 - Visit Wrap Up - Set Up Your Letter Templates:

Frequently-used letters might have been pre-configured by your project team for you to send as Quick
Communications. If so, you will see them when you go to the Communications section:

To send a Quick Communication:

1. Select a recipient if one doesn't appear already.
2. If you want to edit the letter text, click Create under the name of the template.
3. To print the letter, click the Print or Print this communication at Sign Visit button.

If you don't see the desired letter template as a Quick Communication, you can set up additional letter templates
to appear after you click New Communication.

To set up your own speed buttons for your letters and set a default letter template:

1. Near the New Communication button, click the wrench button.  Communication Management User Preferences opens.
2. Use the Default Letter Template field to list the letter template you want to use when you click New
Communication.
3. Use the Letter Template Speed buttons to set up additional speed buttons you want available in the
Communications section.
4. Click Accept.

startupObject.name: Narrowing the story board
startupObject.instructions: Consider Narrow width of story board to give more space for the rest of the layout

startupObject.name: Organize workspace activities
startupObject.instructions:
Organize the navigation tabs to only those the provider uses

Tip 3 - Workspace - Optimize Your Activity Tabs: Page-6

When you are in a patient chart, activity tabs are on the top of the patient workspace. If you frequently use an activity on the More menu ‚ñº, save clicks by moving it to the main set of activity tabs. You can add and remove
activity tabs, as well as modify their order and appearance.

Note: Changes to activity tabs are encounter type-specific. For example, activity tabs you add while in a telephone encounter only impact telephone encounters.

1. In a patient workspace of the desired encounter type (office visit, hospital, etc.), expand the More menu with the downward arrow ‚ñº.
2. Add an activity tab to your workspace:
  ‚Ä¢ Click the push pin next to the activity you want to add, or...
  ‚Ä¢ Click and drag the item from the More menu to your activity tabs.
3. Tabs can also be reordered via drag and drop.

You can also modify the appearance of the activity tabs and the tabs in the sidebar.

1. Right-click the tab you wish to change.
You will get different options depending on if it is the activity tabs or a sidebar tab.
2. Some of the options you will see include:
  ‚Ä¢ Mark as Important: adds an icon to the tab
  ‚Ä¢ Change Highlight Color: changes the background color behind the icon
  ‚Ä¢ Move to More Activities: takes a tab you don't want pinned and nests it back under the More
menu.

startupObject.name: Organize Chart Review Tabs
startupObject.instructions:
Organize the tabs in chart review to hide tabs that are not used

Tip 2 - Chart Review - Change the Tab Order, Tab Colors, and Default Tab: Page-6

Chart Review contains information related to the current patient and is organized into a series of tabs. The tabs
pull together information from the entire patient chart. For example, the Notes tab will have notes from all of the
encounters for the patient and not just the current encounter.

Change the left-to-right tab order so the tabs you use most frequently are in the desired order. You also can add
color highlighting to tabs and select the tab that opens automatically.

1. In Chart Review, click the wrench üîß
to the far right of all the tabs.
2. Select Manage Tabs.
   ‚Ä¢ The Chart Review Tab Settings window opens.
3. Change the order of tabs: Click and drag or use the up/down arrow buttons.
4. Change the color of a tab: Click on the row for that tab. Use the Color field to choose a color.
5. To mark a tab as the default that opens automatically, click the row for that tab. Above the Color field, click
the ‚òÜ.
  ‚Ä¢ Marking a tab as the default does not move its position. For example, if you mark Notes as the
default tab and it is the third tab from the left, it remains in that position but will open automatically when you first open Chart Review.
6. Click Accept.

The same basic steps can be completed by right-clicking on a Chart Review tab (Notes, Encounters, etc.) and using
the right-click menu.

startupObject.name: Layout of `This Visit` Pane
startupObject.instructions:
Change the layout of ‚Äúthis visit‚Äù pane so 
chief complaint

meds

startupObject.name: Organize Preference List
startupObject.instructions:
Organize the orders on preference list into sections. 
For example
Labs
lab panels
Radiology
referrals, etc. 

Some users like to organize by diseases instead. 

Tip 5 - Craft and Use Your Preference List: Page-15

Before diving into preference lists, it is important to understand how the system looks through the library of
available orders every time you search for one. The search behavior behind the scenes looks for matches in the
following order:

1) My Favorites Preference List: This is the list of orders that you can control. Orders you've starred (i.e.
favorited) are stored here.
2) Browse and Preference List: This group of orders is included alongside your user preference list when you
initiate a search. This list is controlled by your project team. Ideally, Physician Builders at your site can also modify
these.
3) Facility List: If you don't find a match in your initial search, consider clicking on the Facility List tab to see if there
are other matches in your clinic formulary. Pharmacists and your Orders team are responsible for maintaining this
list.
4) Database: This tab, although rarely available to clinicians, contains all of the orders that are available across the
entire organization. If you need orders from the database list to be added to your facility or specialty preference
list, you should contact your Orders team.

You can see these preference lists when you click the preference list icon ‚ãÆ‚â° in the visit taskbar.

You can manually select the orders you need from these lists as well. In this session, you will learn some
strategies for organizing your user preference lists. We'll start by getting some orders added, and then we'll
showcase some of the things you can do to make finding those orders easier.

1. Look up and select an order as you normally would. Then edit the order details and click CHECKMARK Accept (or just right-click in any blank space in the Order Composer!).
2. Before signing your order, click ‚òÜ to add it to your preference list.
  ‚óè The Add To Preference List window opens.
3. In the Display name field, enter an easy-to-remember name for the order.
 ‚óè The next time you need to place this order, you can search for your saved order using any of the
words in this name, so include any search terms that will help you find the order later.
 ‚óè You can include a unique abbreviation that is shared by a group of related orders. For example, you
could end all of your STD labs with "*std" so that when you include "*std" in your search, all of
those labs are quickly found.
4. In the Section field, enter the name of the section in which you want this order to appear.
 ‚óè You may click New Section to create your own custom section.
5. Leave the Pref List: field as Orders.
 ‚óè While you can save things on different lists, it does make maintenance somewhat more
complicated, as you have to visit several lists to make updates.
6. Configure any of the order details you want to include when you place this order in the future, such as
instructions, relative dates, diagnosis associations, or answers to questions, and click Accept.
 ‚óè Remember that these details appear only for you, and you can always update them later.

Tip 10 - Create a User Order Panel: Page-21
You have the ability to create their own user order panels.
1. Use the visit taskbar to queue up a group of orders.
2. In the orders cart window, click Options.
3. Select Create Panel.
The order panels that you add on the fly will be stored in an "Orders" type preference list.
4. Add your new panel to an appropriate section with an appropriate title.
Any synonyms or text that you add to the display name will become searchable.
5. Accept the new item.

You can also add new items to the panel later if you right click and Edit Preference List Entry.

startupObject.name: Results
startupObject.instructions:
Results:
Develop quick actions for provider to use for common results: 
for example:
  normal mammogram
  normal Cologuard
  positive covid result
  negative covid result

Tip 7 - Result Management QuickActions: Page-12

Create a Result Management QuickAction

If you respond to Result messages with a routine message, create a Result Note QuickAction. For example, you
can create a single QuickAction that a) creates a note asking a nurse to call the patient, b) sends the note to the
nurse pool, and c) removes the associated Results message from your In Basket.

1. Click Manage QuickActions on the In Basket toolbar to open the QuickAction Manager.
2. Click New QuickAction > Result Mgmt.
3. In the Name field, enter a brief name for your QuickAction, such as Normal - Call.
4. Configure this QuickAction to meet your needs:
 ‚óè To have a chance to edit the result note before it's filed, leave Show note before filing selected.
 ‚óè To automatically remove the associated Results message from your In Basket, select the Mark
message as done checkbox.
5. Specify which results should be attached to your note. In the Selected Results section, choose:
 ‚óè All to attach your notes to all results in a message.
 ‚óè None if you don't want to attach your note to any results. You can choose results on the fly if you
selected the Show note before filing checkbox in step 4. This option is not recommended,
because it's faster to locate your note when it's attached to a result.
 ‚óè Abnormal to select only the abnormal results in a message.
 ‚óè Unreviewed to select only results that have not been marked as reviewed.
6. To send your note to a colleague, enter recipients in the Route To section. For example, send it to the
patient's PCP or to other recipients, like a pool of nurses.
7. Enter your note in the Result Note field on the right.
8. To release the result to the patient, select Release results to MyChart. You can write a comment for the
patient in the MyChart Comment field.
 ‚óè You may use SmartLinks in the Result Note and MyChart Comment text boxes to personalize the
text based on patient information when you use this QuickAction.
9. When you're finished, click Accept.
 ‚óè A new QuickAction button appears to the right of the Folder toolbar when you review Results
messages.

startupObject.name: Message Quick Actions
startupObject.instructions:
Messages:
Develop quick action for a blank note that provider can type/dictate result note that is automatically sent to their nurse pool and then filed to chart.

a. Make sure to teach them to:
NOT USE the arrows for messages that bury the notes in the chart and are not useful in the chain of communication l and then filed to chart.

Tip 8 - Send Message QuickActions: Page-13

f you receive messages that require routine follow-up, you can write and route your standard documentation in a few clicks using a QuickAction.

Create a Staff Message QuickAction

Use QuickActions to send common messages, such as Staff messages, in a few clicks. For example, you could
create a QuickAction to send yourself a reminder Staff message in a week to make sure that a patient's symptoms
have improved. Any QuickActions you create are available from In Basket and within a patient's chart, so you can
quickly send messages about specific patients.

1. On the In Basket toolbar, click the arrow to the right of the Manage QuickActions button and select New Message.
 ‚óè The Send Message QuickAction Editor opens.
2. Enter a brief name for your QuickAction in the Button Name field.
3. In the Message Type field, select the type of message you want to send. This will typically be Staff.
4. When using this as a QuickAction, by default, Epic will show you the message and allow you to make changes before sending. Uncheck Show message before sending if you want the message to be sent
immediately and don't anticipate needing to make a change to it. Note that some message types will not
allow you to deselect this option.
5. Enter your preferred recipients, such as yourself or your clinic's nurse pool, in the To and Cc fields.
6. Configure the rest of the fields to meet your needs:
 ‚óè In the Subject field, enter a title for your message.
 ‚óè At the upper right, optionally change the priority of your message to High or Low.
 ‚óè If you want to distinguish these messages with a flag, select one from the Flags list.
 ‚óè Under Dates, in the Delay sending until field, enter the date you want your message to be sent. If you leave this field blank, the message is sent immediately. Use date shortcuts, such as t for today and w for week. For example, to have the system send your message in a week, enter w+1.
 ‚óè You can do the same thing in the Due on and Expire on fields. The due date will display as a column in In Basket and represents the date after which the message will begin to show up with red, bold text. Expire on means the message will disappear after that time.
 ‚óè Enter your message in the text box.
7. When you're done, click Accept. You may use your new Staff Message QuickAction in the following places:
 ‚óè In your In Basket, by selecting it from the New Message menu on the In Basket toolbar.
   ‚óã Use this method if you don't want a patient to be tied to your message.
 ‚óè In a patient's chart, by clicking More > Send Message and selecting the QuickAction. When you use your QuickAction from a patient's chart, the patient is automatically attached to your message.

startupObject.name: Develop Filters for notes, labs, media
startupObject.instructions:
Develop filters for:
-Notes
-Labs
-Media

Tip 3 - Chart Review - Save Your Filters: Page-73

One of the challenges to efficiency is information not being easily discoverable. On a given tab in Chart Review,
you can set up filters so that you can quickly summarize the information you are interested in. For example, when
you go to the Media tab you might want to only see images of a particular exam (colonoscopy or mammogram),
or on the Encounters tab you might want to see visits with a particular reason for visit.

When you open a tab in Chart Review, you will see some pre-set filters that appear as a series of check boxes next
to the Filters button.

If you don't see a filter that meets your need, you can build your own Quick Filter and save it so it is one-click
away the next time you need it.

1. In Chart Review, go to the desired tab and click Filters.
2. In the filter pane on the left, select the criteria and specific values you want to use for your filter.
 ‚óè If you don't see the value you want to include (because the current patient doesn't have that value in their chart), use the lookup field below the criteria list and your filter will include that search term.
3. Select if you want this to be an inclusive or an exclusive criteria using the Include and Exclude buttons.
‚óè The ability to use exclude filter criteria is available starting in the August 2020 version.
4. At the bottom, click Save as New Filter.
5. Enter a free-text name for your Quick Filter and click Accept.
 ‚óè The filter appears as a check box to the right of the pre-set filters.

Update a filter you created
You can make updates to filters you previously created.

1. In Chart Review go to the tab that has the filter you want to update.
2. Click Filters.
3. Select the filter you want to update.
4. Change the filter for your needs.
5. Click Save <Name of the Filter> to update the filter.
 ‚óè If you wanted to create an additional filter and keep the old filter, click Save as New Filter.

Delete a filter you created
1. In Chart Review, select the tab that has the filter you want to delete.
2. Click üîß on the far right.
3. Select Manage Quick Filters.
 ‚óè Manage Quick Filters window opens.
4. Select the filter you created that you want to delete and click Delete.

startupObject.name: Bookmarks
startupObject.instructions:
Use bookmarks to mark:
-Tests
-Notes
-Labs
Which provider may want to refer to in the future

Tip 7 - Chart Review - Bookmarks: Page-11
Bookmarks allow users to pick and choose reports from multiple Chart Review tabs and add them to the
Bookmarks tab so they can be looked at later. Users can see Bookmarks created by other users, but can only edit
their own. A nurse or MA can read through a patient's chart and call out significant new information for the
doctor to review before seeing the patient.

1. In Chart review, go to any tab and select a relevant item.
2. Click ‚ó§‚ó• to the left of the item, or ‚ó§‚ó•+ Add to Bookmarks on the Chart Review toolbar.

To review the information that has a bookmark, click the tab with the ‚ó§‚ó• icon. If other users have added bookmarks to the patient chart, you will see an Updated Bookmark Lists field.

To select another user's bookmark lists, click the magnifying glass in the field.
